Blog Get Started FAQs

What is Flexible Work?

The business dictionary defines flexible work as “Work practice that allows the employees a certain degree of freedom in deciding how the work will be done and how they'll coordinate their schedules with those of other employees.”

To us, it’s so much more. Flexible work is any arrangement that increase flexibility options by:

  • Empowering workers self-management to improve team productivity
  • Allowing mitigation of environmental impact at the company or individual level
  • Allowing personal work-life balance through choice
  • Improving the chance of equality by removing social barriers
  • Allowing more people to work with and around personal limiting circumstances
  • Streamlining bureaucracy without removing accountability for work responsibilities

Flexible work is the future of work.

How are most companies organising flexibility?

Inefficiently… or not at all.

55% of companies that could easily accommodate basic flexible work solutions do not have any formal policy on flexibility. This reduces the visibility of impact since there are no formal measurements or targets and possible options are not transparently available to employees reducing uptake.

Research suggests options, outside of flexible hours or days and work from home, are often unknown and underutilised.

We have a flexible work policy, why do we need a flexible work strategy?

Policy without action is invisible and options without policy are inefficient and hard to quantify. Flexible work needs to be defined, measured, carefully considered and updated in the same way any every other business strategy would be, to be effective in the long term.

A short term unchecked policy can undermine long term strategy producing unintended and undesired consequences. In that way, flexible work is no different, it can impact every aspect of a business and silently grow (or undermine) a company.

Can you afford to give away that competitive edge?

Why can’t companies just create their own flexible work policies and strategies?

Most companies now have a flexible work policy. It generally sits somewhere on the HR intranet and is often so full of conditions it is far from flexible.

Corporations are starting to realise they need to develop workplace strategies and space efficiency initiatives to future-proof work environments, attract and retain personnel, and mitigate disruption.

What support does Flex By Design offer?

Flex by design aims to offer a holistic approach to flexible work via web and mobile-enabled platform. To design, manage and update a flexible work strategy to maximise the benefit for the company, employee and customer.

Who wants flexible work options?

Everyone… nearly.

In 2012 60% of knowledge-based workers expected to work flexibly, in 2019, that percentage increased to 75%. When asked, 84% of employees would like to have flexible options when they work.

Younger generations see flexibility as a need for life balance and autonomy and older generations want the flexibility to accommodate a gradual shift towards retirement on their own terms.

Everybody benefits from more choice to prioritise day to day needs without sacrificing home or work commitments.

How are most companies supporting flexible work?

In short, they are not sure. Most flexible arrangements are informal agreements between managers and staff leaving them open to abuse and miss-use on both sides. 45% of companies with official flexible work policy are not currently offering tools to support staff with the uptake of flexible work arrangements leaving the success of arrangements up to the individual and team.

How much can we save with flexible work strategy?

That depends on many factors, including:

  • Current overheads from rent and running of central office space
  • Lost time from travel and commuting disruptions
  • Staff turnover and recruitment costs
  • Lost productivity from lowered staff wellbeing

After profiling, analysis and a strategy development pilot Flex By Design will be able to provide a detailed clear indication of potential cost savings in the long term.

Why is a flexible work strategy more cost-effective than just hot-desking and allowing working from home?

While many larger organisations have turned to hot-desking and agile work arrangements, all too often they are perceived as cost cutting initiatives with a one-size fits all approach. This results in unintended consequences where those working entirely from home start to feel isolated, introverts forced to hotdesk can become anxious and teams can become disconnected.

Flex By Design mitigates these issues in three key ways:

  • Profiling:

    Individuals are assessed to determine their workspace needs both in terms of their role, productivity preferences and personal situation.

    This is reviewed against the Company objectives and needs to ensure a holistic approach that benefits all.

  • Co-working:

    The Flex By Design platform connects companies to a network of independent geographically diverse co-working spaces.

    These shared work spaces have been shown to reduce isolation while providing employees with the benefits of access to a more diverse community and exposure to innovative ideas.

  • Technology:

    Flex By Design’s tech-enabled solution, allows managing flexible arrangements to be clear, transparent and easy.
